    HydroEnR-Welcome

    HydroEnR-Welcome.Rmd

    Welcome to the HydroEnR package

    Currently this is just a test page but more documentation will be added over time.

    To load the package use;

    library(HydroEnR)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'HydroEnR'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     window

    QMED

    Let’s import some QMED data from NRFA, the site we’ll use is ‘St Johns Beck at Thirlmere Reservoir’ - ID: 75001

    For this we will require the rnrfa package.

    library(rnrfa)
#> Warning: package 'rnrfa' was built under R version 4.0.5

data <- rnrfa::get_ts(id = 75001, type = 'amax-flow')
data
#>            amax-flow
#> 1974-02-16    16.243
#> 1975-01-22    24.027
#> 1976-01-02     0.818
#> 1977-02-07     8.913
#> 1977-10-31    20.196
#> 1978-11-15     1.235
#> 1979-12-27    21.760
#> 1980-12-13    25.240
#> 1982-02-10    17.417
#> 1982-12-19    16.079
#> 1984-02-07     3.632
#> 1985-09-21    10.674
#> 1985-12-21    38.943
#> 1986-11-25    25.794
#> 1988-01-09    16.658
#> 1989-03-09    36.551
#> 1990-02-19    21.651
#> 1991-03-19    21.781
#> 1991-10-31     1.497
#> 1993-01-24    10.572
#> 1994-03-23    14.790
#> 1995-01-31    46.124
#> 1996-01-13     7.035
#> 1997-03-02    11.539
#> 1998-03-07     9.451
#> 1999-01-06    27.152
#> 2000-01-12    22.193
#> 2000-12-05    24.599
#> 2002-02-11    22.977
#> 2002-10-27     0.652
#> 2004-02-03    17.888
#> 2005-01-08    47.746
#> 2005-11-11     6.333
#> 2006-12-11    32.431
#> 2008-01-14    19.742
#> 2008-10-23    31.950
#> 2009-11-19    59.840
#> 2011-02-09     8.695
#> 2012-01-04    10.780
#> 2012-12-31    22.058
#> 2014-02-24    20.196
#> 2015-01-01    23.304
#> 2015-12-05    75.353
#> 2017-03-31     1.710
#> 2017-11-22     2.832
#> 2019-03-16    20.839
#> 2020-02-09    28.101

    To find the QMED we will use the QMED function;

    qmed <- QMED(data)
qmed
#> [1] 20.196

    Now we’ll make a plot of the data

    plotQMED(data)
#> [1] Estimated QMED: 20.196 cumecs

    L-moments

    Within HydroEnR we can calculate the L-moments individually or as a grouped function.

    To calculate the L1;

    L1(data)
#> [1] 20.34023

    You can also apply an urban adjustment. For this you can nest the function

    urbAdj(LCV(data), URBEXT2000 = 0.3)
#> [1] 0.3326938

    Alternatively, you can use a piping operator from the magrittr library. In this example we will set the DeUrb parameter to TRUE, normally set to FALSE.

    library(magrittr)
LCV(data) %>% 
  urbAdj(URBEXT2000 = 0.3, DeUrb = TRUE)
#> [1] 0.4738179

    Using the Ls() function HydroEnR can bundle up all the L-moment calculations;

    Ls(data)
#>         L1       L2       L3      L4       LCV       LCA      LKUR     LSkew
#> 1 20.34023 8.075772 1.588365 1.73832 0.3970343 0.1966827 0.2152513 0.1966827
#>     QMED
#> 1 20.196

    Urban adjustments can also be added with the URBEXT2000 and DeUrb parameters

    Ls(data, URBEXT2000 = 0.3, DeUrb = FALSE)
#>         L1       L2       L3      L4       LCV       LCA      LKUR     LSkew
#> 1 20.34023 8.075772 1.588365 1.73832 0.3326938 0.1966827 0.2152513 0.2493874
#>     QMED
#> 1 20.196
